results.title: Painters painting (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Emile de Antonio, Mary Lampson and Turin Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This is a film about the postwar New York art scene featuring interviews with de Kooning, Rauschenberg, Stella, Poons, Johns, Motherwell, Warhol and others. It was a scene that de Antonio knew intimately. In line with his oeuvre, de Antonio saw this film as political. It was made with enthusiasm for the artists and their art but also with an awareness of the contradictions: commodification involving a network of two or three thousand people - the painters, the collectors, the owners and the dealers - although this is no more than implicit in the film.

results.title: Painters of Quebec
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree, Graham McInnes and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents seven painters of Quebec: Suzor Cote, Clarence Gagnon, Marc-Aurele Fortin, Jean-Paul Lemieux, Alfred Pellan, Henri Masson and Andre Beiler. Narrated by Marius Barbeau.

results.title: Deep threat = Mer mere
results.creator_credit: Don Arioli, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Humour helps bring home a serious point in this animated, wordless film. The sea has its own laws and man is accountable to them. Man is shown evolving from the sea, then developing industry and the wastes that pollute that same sea. (Awards: Toulon, San Antonio)

results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: mixed media, interactive video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Paddle to the sea
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A children’s odyssey, from the story by Holling C. Holling. A film about a little Indian in a canoe, hand-carved in the northern forest and, in the spring, launched towards the sea. There are many adventures, all photographed with great patience and an eye for the beauty of living things. The film gives vivid impressions of Canada’s varied landscape and the life of its waterways. Commentary by Stanley Jackson. Awards: ten awards including Philadelphia; Oscar nomination, Hollywood.

results.title: Deep sea drilling project
results.creator_credit: Jack Robinson and National Science Foundation
results.brief_description: Shows how ocean bottom cores are obtained and what they tell about the drifting of continents throughout the ages. Documents the voyages of the Clomar Challenger, a new class of drilling ship able to probe deep beneath the floors of the oceans.

results.title: Pablo Picasso Peintre = Pablo Picasso Painter
results.brief_description:
A biography of Pablo Picasso, abundantly illustratd with home movies and newsreels. The purpose of the filmmaker is to explain how the painter came to embody the 20th century.

Credits: Director, Frederic Rossif ; writer, Helene Parmelin ‘ photography, Daniel barrau ; music, Vangelis Papathanassiou.
Cast: Suzanne Flon, Pierre Vaneck [narration only].
